text.p:
Riddles and Enigmas
English and Gaelic
by
Alexander Nicolson , M . A .
Lecturer in Gaelic
at Jordanhill College & University , Glasgow .

GLASGOW
ALEXANDER MACLAREN & SONS ,
GAELIC PUBLISHERS AND BOOKSELLERS
268 ARGYLE STREET ,

Gaelic Riddles and Enigmas
[Toimhseachain agus Dubh - Fhacail]

ALEX . MACLAREN & SONS
Publishers & Booksellers
268 Argyle Street
GLASGOW , C . 2 .

Ceithir casan ’ s a mhaduinn ,
A dha am feasgar ,
Agus tri am beul na h - oidhche . *

* When Oedipus repaired to Thebes , in order to escape that fate the oracle had pronounced on him at birth , he found the inhabitants driven to despair by the action of a sphinx that slew all who attempted to enter , or to leave , the city unless they could answer a riddle . In their desperation the Thebans offered the kingdom to any who should free them from the imposition of the monster ; and it is said that Oedipus volunteered to sacrifice himself for their deliverance . Accordingly , he approached the sphinx , and was asked — “ What being has 4 feet , 2 feet , and 3 feet , at different times of its life , and is weakest when it has most ? ” On being given the answer that it is — Man , the ogre hurled itself to death from the precipice on which it was perched , and thus the Thebans were freed from its spell .

A ’ mhuc a thainig a Eirinn ,
’ S ann oirre fein a bha an eiginn shearbh :
Tri tonna , tri tanna ,
Muc air fhichead ’ us fichead mheanbh .
— NA TRI STUADHAN MORA AN CLIATH - THONN RI STOIRM . *
* The three large waves that come together at intervals during a storm .

Anna beag a ’ chota bhain ,
Mar is motha a ghabhas i , *
’ S mar is faide a sheasas i ,
Is ann is lugha a bhitheas i a ’ fas .
— COINNEAL .
* A play on the word — Gabh — which means — to take , as well as — to kindle .

Chunnacas ionghnadh leam an diugh ,
’ S ma ’ s ionghnadh leam is ionghnadh dhut : —
Ceithir daimh* gun fhuil , gun fheoil ,
A ’ spionadh feoir a talamh dubh .
— CLIATH - CHLIATHTA .
* A pun on a rare meaning of “ daimh ” which is the large beams of the harrow in which the teeth are inserted .

Da rud bheaga dhubha co - ionnan ri a cheile ;
Tha aon diubh uile cearr* ’ us aon diubh uile ceart ;
Ach nan robh an t - aon tha uile ceart
Air a dheanamh uile cearr ,
Bhitheadh an t - aon tha uile cearr ,
Air a dheanamh uile ceart .
— PAIDHIR BHROG , NO MHAITEAGAN .
* This is a pun on the word “ cearr , ” which is equivalent to “ wrong ” as well as “ left . ”

*Is gile i na canach an t - sleibhe ,
Is gile i na leine , no anart ;
Is meanbh - bhruc i na uchd na druide ,
Agus olaidh i mar gheibh i .
— LITIR .
* This was received from Archd . MacPherson , Ollach , Skye .

Co an t - each agus an lair nach facas riamh a ’ treabhadh ?
— EACH - UISGE AGUS LAIR - MHAIDE . †

Co an crann nach dean treabhadh ged chuireadh tu daoine ’ ga stiuireadh , agus eich ’ ga tharraing ?
— CRANN - SGADAIN . ‡

† Literally — “ wooden mare . ”
‡ Pun on word “ crann , ” which is equivalent to “ plough , ” and also to “ four baskets of fish . ”

Ciod iad tri mallachdan an tuathanaich ?
— REODHADH CEITEIN , CEO IUCHAR , AGUS AN TAOITEAR SAILEACH . *
* This was Sir Roderick Mackenzie , tutor to the first Earl of Seaforth , who was detested for rack - renting the tenantry . It was he who overcame the resistance of the MacLeods of Lewis .

Ciod is miosa de bhiadh ?
— BLIANACH , AGUS OL CORMA* AIR A ’ CHEUD LONGADH .

* Posidonius , the Stoic , a traveller of the 1st century , whose works have been lost , is quoted by Atheneus , who lived in the 3rd century , as saying of the Celts : — “ The poor make beer from wheat and mix it with honey . — They called it ‘ Korma . ’ ”

* An analogous riddle is associated with Homer . It is — “ Two boys went to hunt in a secluded place . What they caught they threw away , and what they did not catch they took home . ” Tradition has it that Homer failed to answer it , though it would be obvious to any dirty tinker boy .

Cia mar a thaghadh Fionn a chu ?
Suil mar airneig ,
Cluas mar dhuilleig ,
Uchd mar ghearran ,
Speir mar chorran ,
’ San t - alt - luthaidh fad ’ bho ’ n cheann . *
* These are obviously points in a good hunting dog .

Thiodhlaic mi mo naoi nigheannean , mar shneachdnar , An Cille - mo - Neachdain ann an I .
*Chaidh dithis a chur ’ san aon uaigh aig da am .

*Cf . —
Cladh Cill Da - Bhi
Thiodhlaic mi mo naoinear ann mar thri
An nochd is dubhach Doirbhean
An deidh na cloinne caoimhe .
— Vide C . P . N . S . , p . 308 .

Da chois shios
Tri casan shuas
’ Us ceann a ’ bheo am beul a ’ mhairbh .
— NEACH AGUS POIT THRI - CHASACH AIR A CHEANN . *

* I have a vivid recollection of an occasion during boyhood , when , returning from the hills after the celebration of Easter , one of the party put the three - legged pot in which the eggs were cooked , mouth downwards , on his head . On his leaping over an obstruction the pot slipped over his head and encased it so firmly that we were forced to break the pot in order to release the lad .
Ged a mholadh tu am mol , chan fhas am mol molach . *

* This is a pun on the word —
“ mol . ”

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
Printed by
Archibald Sinclair , “ Celtic Press , ”
27a Cadogan Street ,
Glasgow .
